EPsy 8251 (Fall 2017) Welcome to Andy’s EPsy 8251: Methods in Data Analysis for Educational Research I website. This site is intended to complement the course syllabus by serving as an organizational hub for the course. Here you will be able to access course materials such as readings, notes, assignments, and data sets. It also includes helpful links and resources for each of the course topics. Office Hours Andy Zieffler (zief0002@umn.edu) Tuesday 9:30AM–10:30AM (and by appointment) Education Sciences Building 178 Downloading Materials You can download all of the course materials from the Github repository. Or, you can simply click this link to download a ZIP file of all the materials. Individual files can also be downloaded from the Course Resources page. R and RStudio The course uses R and RStudio. First download and install R from http://www.r-project.org/. Then download and install RStudio from http://www.rstudio.org/.

Course Resources Syllabus Spring 2017 Syllabus Textbook There are two textbooks for the course. Links are provided when the book is available via the University of Minnesota library. [Required] Lewis-Beck, C., & Lewis-Beck, M. (2016). Applied regression: An introduction (2nd ed.). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. [Optional] Nicol, A. A., & Pexman, P. M. (2010). Presenting your findings: A practical guide to creating tables (6th ed.). Washington, DC: American Psychological Association. Data Sets beauty.csv mnSchools.csv movies.csv regional-colleges.csv riverside.csv
Assignments Checking. Interesting. ah. Let’s try a link: Syllabus
Course Topics Here is a map of the topics we will cover in EPsy 8251.

Introduction to R and RStudio To prepare for class: Install R and RStudio on your computer. Watch the video R for Starters: R and R Studio Workspace Here are other R and RStudio resources you may want to explore: RStudio Keyboard Shortcuts R for Data Science

Plotting with ggplot2 To prepare for class, watch the videos: Plotting with ggplot: Part 1 Plotting with ggplot: Part 2 Here are other ggplot2 resources you may want to explore: ggplot2 Cheatsheet ggplot2 Extensions Data Stories podcast: ggplot2, R, and data toolmaking with Hadley Wickham Wickham, H. (2010). A layered grammar of graphics. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 19(1), 3–28.
Data Wrangling with dplyr To prepare for class, read: dplyr Vignette Here are other dplyr resources you may want to explore: dplyr Cheatsheet -Data Wrangling with R and RStudio
Simple Linear Regression: Description To prepare for class, read: Lewis-Beck & Lewis-Beck (Chap. 1) Here are other resources you may want to explore: Guess the Correlation Game
Simple Linear Regression: Inference To prepare for class, read: Lewis-Beck & Lewis-Beck (Chap. 2) Here are other resources you may want to explore: Dance of the p-values
Multiple Regression To prepare for class, read: Lewis-Beck & Lewis-Beck (Chap. 3) Here are other resources you may want to explore: Confounding Variables
Regression Assumptions To prepare for class, re-read: Lewis-Beck & Lewis-Beck (Chap. 2) Here are other resources you may want to explore: Visualizing Residuals

Categorical Predictors To prepare for class, read: What is Dummy Coding? What is Effect Coding? Here are other resources you may want to explore: fiveThirtyEight: p-Hacking Gelman, A., Hill, J., & Yajima, M. (2012). Why we (usually) don’t have to worry about multiple comparisons. Journal of Research on Educational Effectiveness, 5, 189–211. Regression with dummy variables

Interaction Models To prepare for class, read: Brambor, T., Clark, W. R., & Golder, M. (2006). Understanding interaction models: Improving empirical analyses. Political Analysis, 14, 63–82. doi:10.1093/pan/mpi014

Nonlinearity: Polynomial Models To prepare for class: Read Math is Fun: Quadratic Equations Watch the video Polynomial Regression (Coursera) Here are other resources you may want to explore: Math is Fun: Polynomials

Nonlinearity: Log-Transformations To prepare for class: Read through Interpreting log-transformed predictors/outcomes Here are other resources you may want to explore: Was the Nepal Earthquake Twice as Big as We Thought? -->
